Award.AwardTitle: Fate of foreign genes in experimental evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
The transfer of DNA between bacteria in the environment has important consequences. When DNA is passed from one organism to another in a fashion that does not involve a parent providing genetic material to its offspring, the process is called horizontal gene transfer (HGT). This type of inheritance contributes significantly to human health, biotechnology, and fundamental mechanisms of evolution. For example, HGT underlies the serious problem of bacterial resistance to antibiotics. Beneficial aspects of HGT include the ability of bacteria to detoxify pollutants. HGT also holds exciting promise for applications that enable bacteria to produce useful compounds, including fuels. This project focuses on the fate of foreign DNA after it has been transferred to a new bacterial host. A novel experimental system will facilitate investigations of HGT to improve understanding of how genetic material functions and adapts in diverse contexts. These studies will be used to develop and improve techniques that accelerate the success of biotechnology applications. The researchers have a successful history of training students at all levels and in enhancing diversity and inclusiveness in the scientific community, including training of students with disabilities. This project will be used to augment such activities. Furthermore, this project involves collaborations with researchers at the National Renewable Energy Lab to develop applications in bioenergy production. Training opportunities will enable students to visit and conduct research at this national laboratory.

An accelerated approach to experimental evolution will be used to follow the fate of foreign genes after their insertion into the chromosome of a soil bacterium, Acinetobacter baylyi. These genes will be amplified in a tandem array to enable copy number of the repeated segment (amplicon) to increase or decrease spontaneously. This process of expansion and contraction allows evolution of rudimentary control of the expression of newly acquired genes. This experimental system mimics the natural interplay between HGT and gene amplification. Gene dosage can increase a weak but beneficial function provided by foreign DNA. As mutations accrue within the amplicons, gene copies that are less fit will be lost and alleles that are more fit may increase via selection. This project exploits gene amplification to accelerate the evolutionary process so that gene divergence can be the focus of experimental study. Additional studies will alter the genetic content of the foreign DNA, changing synonymous codon usage, G+C content and chromosomal location. It will then be possible to test how these alterations affect the amelioration and retention of the genes. Strains will be grown under continuous culture in controlled environments. Copy number, mRNA, protein and DNA sequence changes will be analyzed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of evolution, genetic changes facilitate adaptation to new or changing environments. One mechanism that can alter cellular functionality involves acquisition of DNA from another organism (horizontal transfer) in a fashion that differs from genetic transmission from parent to offspring (vertical inheritance). Although horizontal gene transfer is known to play a significant role in evolution, it remains unclear exactly how foreign DNA gets fully incorporated in a new host. The newly acquired DNA must be properly expressed and regulated to confer advantageous traits. One goal of this project is to improve understanding of this fundamentally important evolutionary process. Our novel experimental system allows the relatively rapid selection of new bacterial traits in the laboratory. Publications resulting from this NSF grant describe our method, called Evolution by Amplification and Synthetic biology (EASy), in which foreign DNA is specifically inserted into the chromosome of a soil bacterium, Acinetobacter baylyi ADP1. The chromosome can be readily manipulated because this bacterium has an unusually high natural proclivity to take up DNA from the environment and to recombine it when there is sufficient sequence identity (homologous recombination). The experimental innovation developed in this project allows the generation of an array of adjacent copies of a precisely defined chromosomal region carrying the foreign DNA (amplification). The goal of the amplification step, which increases expression of the foreign DNA, is to mimic, and also accelerate, what can occur during natural horizontal gene transfer. Thus, subsequent steps in which genetic changes optimize new functionality occur in a time frame that can be monitored and characterized in the laboratory.

These studies focused on the evolution of A. baylyi strains that gained the ability to consume a novel aromatic compound, guaiacol, as its sole source of carbon and energy. Initially, the introduction of foreign genes, which were predicted to encode an enzyme needed for this trait, failed to confer the ability to grow on guaiacol. After amplification and evolution in the laboratory, numerous bacteria had this new capability, and the underlying genetic changes were determined. Two types of beneficial changes in the foreign DNA were selected.  One type of change altered the foreign enzyme. The most common change to this enzyme resulted in its physical fusion to a native enzyme. This linkage may affect the movement of metabolites between enzymes. In the fused enzyme, the product of one reaction serves as the substrate of the next. In this case, proximity between the two catalytic active sites may provide selective advantage. The second type of change altered the regulatory region upstream of the foreign DNA. This change appeared to affect post-transcriptional regulation, and it led to the discovery of a previously unrecognized system for global regulation of aromatic compound degradation in A. baylyi. In addition to these changes in the vicinity of the foreign DNA, mutations elsewhere in the chromosome were found to affect various regulatory factors. Collectively, these results demonstrated the utility of the EASy method, identified genetic changes that integrate the foreign genes and enzymes with native metabolism, and revealed new regulatory circuits in A. baylyi. Furthermore, a computational component of this project addressed the evolution of regulatory networks, which in turn allows foreign genes to be integrated into the regulatory networks of the host (Mrazek and Karls, 2019).

There are broader implications of expanding bacterial aromatic compound degradation through metabolic engineering and laboratory evolution. The bacterial degradation of such compounds can be used for biotechnology applications such as cleaning up pollution (bioremediation), synthesizing useful compounds (e.g. biodegradable plastics), and generating valuable products from renewable biomass feedstocks (lignin or lignocellulose valorization). One such biotechnology application was described in a publication resulting from this project (Singh et al., 2019). This project has additional significance in training, education, and promoting inclusion and diversity in scientific endeavors. Numerous students and scientists were involved in the research, including undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and senior scientists. The unique genetic system of A. baylyi was used in an experiential laboratory course that dovetailed with this project in which undergraduate students conducted authentic research studies. One publication from this course resulted, which was partially funded by this NSF grant (Stoudenmire et al., 2017).
